member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.IsFixed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if the specified position in Layer2 contains a vertex with a fixed IndexInLayer defined by the user.
member.param: The index of the position to check.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.SetFixedVertices(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Sets the vertices with fixed positions and returns the total number of fixed vertices.
member.returns: The total number of fixed vertices.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.GetNumberOfCrossings
member.summary: Gets the number of crossings for the initial ordering of layer 2, i.e. 0, 1, 2, ..., n.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.GetNumberOfCrossings(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Calculates the number of crossings between 2 layers using the edge-crossing matrix.
member.param: The order of the vertices in the second layer.
member.remarks: The matrix is iterated through from bottom to top. We find the index of the first cell containig true on the current row and then we increase the number of edge crossings by the number of the cells that contain true and which index is greater than the index of the first cell containing true on the current row. After that we move to the upper row and repeat the whole procedure. And so on until we reach row 1.
member.returns: The number of edge crossings between 2 adgjacent layers.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.ApplyOrderToLayer(Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphVertexList,System.Int32[])
member.summary: Applies a new order of the vertices for a given layer.
member.param: The new order. The meaning of the array is as follows: in order[0] is stored the index in Layer2 of the vertex that should be first, in order[2] is the index of the vertex that should be second in the final ordering and so no.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.m_nVertexCount1
member.summary: The number of vertices in layer 1.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphCrossingReductorBase.m_nVertexCount2
member.summary: The number of vertices in layer 2.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphFullCrossingReductor
member.summary: Investigates all possible permutations and provides an optimal solution for the one sided crossing reduction problem.
member.remarks: Note that finding an optimal solution is an NP-hard problem and requires N! time where N is the number of vertices in the non-fixed layer. Use this method for no more than 8 vertices.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphFullCrossingReductor.#ctor(Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphVertexList,Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphVertexList)
member.summary: Initializing constructor.

member.summary: Reduces the edge crossings in the given bipartite graph and returns the number of crosings after the reduction.
member.returns: The total number of crossings after the reduction process.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.DataStructures.NGraphGeneticCrossingReductor
member.summary: Solves the crossing reduction problem by using genetic algorithm.
member.remarks: Through some tests the optimal parameters of the genetic algorithm were determined as follows: Population Size = 50 Mutation Rate = 0.03

member.summary: Reduces the edge crossings in the given bipartite graph and returns the number of crosings after the reduction.
member.returns: The total number of crossings after the reduction process.

member.summary: Implements a generalized Dijkstra's algorithm to calculate the shortest path problem.
member.remarks: For this algorithm, all nodes should be provided, and handled in the delegate methods, including the start and finish nodes.

member.summary: Initializing constructor.

member.summary: Determines whether this is a strongly connected digraph (directed graph)

member.summary: Determines whether this is a biconnected graph.
member.remarks: A biconnected graph is a nonseparable graph, meaning if any vertex were to be removed, the graph will remain connected.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NWinFormControlHostPrimitive.fnCE.PerformFlush(System.ComponentModel.Design.Serialization.IDesignerSerializationManager)
member.summary: This method is called by the designer host whenever it wants the designer loader to flush any pending changes. Flushing changes does not mean the same thing as saving to disk. For example, In Visual Studio, flushing changes causes new code to be generated and inserted into the text editing window. The user can edit the new code in the editing window, but nothing has been saved to disk. This sample adheres to this separation between flushing and saving, since a flush occurs whenever the code windows are displayed or there is a build. Neither of those items demands a save.

member.summary: Gets/sets the spring stiffness for a shape, which is threated as a spring. Used by force directed layouts with a spring force. Applicable for 1D shapes only. When set to -1 the shape uses the default spring stiffness.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.SpringLength
member.summary: Gets/sets the spring length for a shape, which is threated as a spring. Used by force directed layouts with a spring force. Applicable for 1D shapes only. When set to -1 the shape uses the default spring length.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.UseDefaultMagnetizationType
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the layout default magnetization type must be used.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.MagnetizationType
member.summary: Gets/sets the magnetization type for a shape, which is threated as a magnetized needle trying to align itself with a magnetic field. Used by force directed layouts with magnetic forces. Applicable for 1D shapes only, when UseDefaultMagnetizationType is set to false.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.ForceXMoveable
member.summary: Gets/sets whether a shape is moveable by force directed layouts in the X direction. Used by force directed layouts. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.ForceYMoveable
member.summary: Gets/sets whether a shape is moveable by force directed layouts in the Y direction. Used by force directed layouts. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.ElectricalCharge
member.summary: Gets/sets the electrical charge of a shape, which is threated as electrically charged partical. Used by force directed layouts with electrical force. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.Mass
member.summary: Gets/sets the mass of a shape, which is threated as a physical body with a certain mass (weight). Used by force directed layouts with a baricenter force. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.TipOverChildrenPlacement
member.summary: Gets/sets the children placement of a 2D shape. Used by tip over tree layout. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.UseDefaultHorizontalContentPlacement
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the layout default horizontal content placement must be used.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.HorizontalContentPlacement
member.summary: Gets/sets how the shape is resized/repositioned horizontally to fit the cell slot allocated by a cells layout. Used by all cells layouts (stack, flow, dock etc.). Applicable for 2D shapes only, when UseDefaultHorizontalContentPlacement is set to false.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.UseDefaultVerticalContentPlacement
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the layout default vertical content placement must be used.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.VerticalContentPlacement
member.summary: Gets/sets how the shape is resized/repositioned vertically to fit the cell slot allocated by a cells layout. Used by all cells layouts (stack, flow, dock etc.). Applicable for 2D shapes only, when UseDefaultVerticalContentPlacement is set to false.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.DockArea
member.summary: Gets/sets the docking area occupied by the shape when it is threated as a docking cell. Used by dock layout. Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.UseShapeWidth
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the current shape width is the desired width of the shape

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.DesiredWidth
member.summary: Gets/sets the desired width of the shape. Used by all layouts. Applicable for 2D shapes only, when UseShapeWidth is false. By default set to 0

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.UseShapeHeight
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the current shape height is the desired height of the shape

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.DesiredHeight
member.summary: Gets/sets the desired height of the shape. Used by all layouts. Applicable for 2D shapes only, when UseShapeHeight is false. By default set to 0

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.MinSize
member.summary: Gets/sets the min size of the shape. Used by all cells layouts (stack, flow, dock etc.). Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.MaxSize
member.summary: Gets/sets the max size of the shape. Used by all cells layouts (stack, flow, dock etc.). Applicable for 2D shapes only.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.IndexInLayer
member.summary: Determines the index of the node in its layer when Layered Graph Layout is applied. By default set to -1, which means that the index will be determined automatically.
member.remarks: If you want the node to be the first in its layer set this property to 0. If set it to a value greater than or equal to the number of vertices in the layer, the node will be placed last in the layer. If the value of this property is negative the node index in the layer will be determined by the Layered Graph Layout algorithm.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayoutData.LayerIndex
member.summary: Determines layer index of the node when Layered Graph Layout is applied. By default set to -1, which means that the index will be determined automatically.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager
member.summary: The NRoutingManager attribute is used to provide the container, which hosts it with the ability to route the routable shape it contains

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.#ctor(Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager)
member.summary: Copy constructor

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.ConvertMeasurementUnit(Nevron.GraphicsCore.NMeasurementUnitConverter,Nevron.GraphicsCore.NMeasurementUnit,Nevron.GraphicsCore.NMeasurementUnit)
member.summary: Called when the measurement unit of the measurements stored in this attribute have changed and all measurements must be converted to the new unit

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.Enabled
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the routing manager is enabled. Setting this property to false will globally disable automatic routing.
member.remarks: By default set to true.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.RoutingGridType
member.summary: Controls the type of routing grid created for the routing of HV (orthogonal) routes
member.remarks: By default set to SidesAndCenters

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.RoutingMeshType
member.summary: Controls the type of routing mesh created for the routing of polyline and curved routes
member.remarks: By default set to CornersAndMiddles

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.AvoidInvisibleObstacles
member.summary: Indicates whether invisible obstacles should be avoided by routes
member.remarks: By default set to false

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.ChangeDirectionCost
member.summary: Gets/sets the cost for making a turn (change direction). Applicable for grid routing only

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.ObstacleInteriorDeflate
member.summary: Gets/sets the deflate of the non intersectable obstacles (2D shapes) interior

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.ObstaclePadding
member.summary: Gets/sets the padding applied to the obstacles (2D shapes) bounds

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.MergePointDistance
member.summary: Controls the distance between two routing points, below which the routing points are considered identical

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.MaxAvoidedGridObstacles
member.summary: Controls the maximum count of obstacles (2D shapes) for which grid routing must be performed
member.remarks: By default set to 100

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.MaxAvoidedMeshObstacles
member.summary: Controls the maximum count of obstacles (2D shapes) for which mesh routing must be performed
member.remarks: By default set to 50

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.IsPaused
member.summary: Determines whether the routing manager is currently paused

member.summary: Pauses the routing manager

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NRoutingManager.Resume
member.summary: Resumes the routing manager

member.summary: Specifies the strength (area) in which the guidelines attracts coordinates (in pixels)

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NSnapStrength.GeometryPoints
member.summary: Specifies the strength (area) in which the geometry points attract points (in pixels)
member.remarks: By default set to 10

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NSnapStrength.Ports
member.summary: Specifies the strength (area) in which the ports attract points (in pixels)
member.remarks: By default set to 30

member.summary: The NSnapTargets class represents an attribute, which is used to control the targets to which elements and points are snapped

member.summary: Default constructor. Sets all permissions to true

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NSnapTargets.None

member.summary: Specifies whether coordinates should be snapped to the grid

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NSnapTargets.GeometryPoints
member.summary: Specifies whether to snap to geometry points
member.remarks: By default set to true

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NSnapTargets.Ports
member.summary: Specifies whether to snap to shape ports
member.remarks: By default set to true

member.summary: Gets/sets the mask used to control the snap targets

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Batches.NBatchLayout
member.summary: The NBatchLayout class is used to provide transaction based layout operations
member.remarks:
The Build method filters the building nodes for valid bounds. Once the batch is built you can execute the following set of layout commands:
Alignment helps you align nodes to a virtual grid, align their lefts, rights, tops and bottoms as well as align their centers and middles
Resize helps you size to nodes to a virtual grid, make their size, width and height identical, as well as increase the nodes width and height
Horizontal spacing helps you increase, decrease, remove and make equal the horizontal spacing of nodes
Vertical spacing helps you increase, decrease, remove and make equal the vertical spacing of nodes
Center in document helps you center the nodes horizontally or vertically in the document

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NPortCollection
member.summary: The NPortCollection is a strongly typed collection containing NPort instances
member.remarks:
The NPortCollection provides a two types of default ports: a default inward port and a default outward port.
The default inward port is controlled by the DefaultInwardPortUniqueId property. When set to Guid.Empty the the DefaultInwardPort property will return the first inward port in the collection. The default inward port is used in implicit connections when the inward port in the connection is not explicitly specified (e.g. in the FromShape, ToShape and OutwardShape property setters)
Similarly the default outward port is controlled by the DefaultOutwardPortUniqueId property. When set to Guid.Empty the the DefaultOutwardPort property will return the first outward port in the collection. The default outward port is used in implicit connections when the outward port in the connection is not explicitly specified (e.g. in the OutwardShape property setter)
Since the default ports are referenced by their ids, the NPortCollection class implements the INDiagramElementReferenceHolder interface.

member.summary: Default constructor

member.remarks: Overriden to replace the default port id
member.param: map of ids which is used to find the new foreign id value
indicates whether the not found foreign ids must be set to Guid.Empty

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NPaintContext.MustDisplayNodeAsSelected(Nevron.Dom.INNode)
member.summary: Determines whether the node must be displayed as selected
member.remarks: The node must be displayed as selected if either its or some ot its ancestors hashcodes reside as key in the SelectedNodes table. This method is internally called by the ActivateAppearance method.
member.returns: true if the node must be displayed as selected, otherwise false

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NPaintContext.MustDisplayNodeAsHighlighted(Nevron.Dom.INNode)
member.summary: Determines whether the node must be displayed as highlighted
member.remarks: The node must be displayed as highlighted if either its or some ot its ancestors hashcodes reside as key in the HighlightedNodes table. This method is internally called by the ActivateAppearance method.
member.returns: true if the node must be displayed as highlighted, otherwise false

member.param: diagram element whose permissions to check
member.returns: true if the element can be painted, otherwise false

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NPaintContext.ActivateAppearance(Nevron.Dom.INNode,Nevron.GraphicsCore.NFillStyle,Nevron.GraphicsCore.NStrokeStyle)
member.summary: Activates the node appearance
member.remarks: If appearance activation has been locked this method will do nothing and return false. If the context has valid InteractiveAppearance, this method will override the node fillStyle and stokeStyle if the node must be displayed as selected or highlighted.
member.returns: true if the actual fill style or stroke style activated in the device differs from the ones passed as arguments, otherwise false

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NDrawingDocument
member.summary: The NDrawingDocument class represents a diagram document, which can be used for generic drawing
member.remarks:
The content of each drawing is divided in layers. The layers of a drawing are accessible from the Layers property. Of all layers in a drawing only one can be active. The active layer is obtained from the ActiveLayer property and is controlled by the ActiveLayerUniqueId property.
The content of a drawing is measured in logical measurement units. The logical measurement unit is controlled by the MeasurementUnit property. The measurement unit in which the content is painted is called world measurement unit. In case there is no drawing scale the world measurement unit is equal to the logical measurement unit.
The bounds of the drawing are measured in the logical measurement unit. The drawing bounds can be calculated in several modes:
CustomNonConstrained
User defined bounds are used. The descendant nodes can be placed outside the drawing bounds.
CustomConstrained
User defined bounds are used. The descendant nodes cannot be placed outside the drawing bounds.
AutoSizeToContent
The drawing bounds are automatically sized to the content bounds.
AutoInflateToContent
The document bounds are automatically inflated to contain the content bounds.
In case the mode is set to AutoInflateToContent or AutoSizeToContent, the drawing will take into accout the AutoBoundsPadding property (controls the padding applied to the computed bounds) and the AutoBoundsMinSize property (controls the minimal size of automatic bounds).

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NDocument
member.summary: The NDocument class is a component, which implements core DOM document features and serves as base class for all types of diagram documents
member.remarks:
The NDocument class is the root of a diagram elements hierarchy and as such it implements the core Nevron DOM INDocument interface.
The services exposed by the document are maintained in an instance of the NServiceManager class, which is accessible from the ServiceManager property. Currently the NDocument class registers the following services:
NDocumentEventSinkService
All events are routed to this service. A reference to this service can be obtained from the EventSinkService property.
NDocumentSmartPaintService
This service is used by elements to invalidate themselves (request to be repainted) in all views. A reference to this service can be obtained from the SmartPaintService property.
NDocumentHistoryService
This service is used by elements to record history operations and transactions. A reference to this service can be obtained from the HistoryService property.
A single document can be displayed by multiple views. The NDocument class is responsible for maintainging a list of the views currently displaying it.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NGuideline
member.summary: The abstract NGuideline class represents a guideline to which X or Y coordinates can be snapped and serves as base class for horizontal and vertical guidelines.
member.remarks: NGuideline exposes properties, which are common for both horizontal and vertical guidelines.

member.remarks: By default the AllowCopy permission of guidelines is set to false, so that guidelines cannot be recreated from the Clipboard or Drag and Drop operations.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NAggregateModel

member.remarks: Although the aggregate model is an element container, the models which an aggregate model aggregates may not be it's direct children. It is up to derived classes to override the GetAggregatedModels method in order to provide the aggregate with the models it should aggregate.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NModel.IsInputKey(System.Windows.Forms.Keys)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified key is an input key
member.remarks: This method is called by views when this model is the focused model. The implementation will first invoke the QueryIsInputKey method of the document for this model. If the key is not an input key for this model it will call the QueryIsInputKey method again passing as argument the document itself.
member.returns: true if the key is an input key, otherwise false

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NDiagramElement
member.summary: The NDiagramElement abstract class serves as base class for all elements, which can reside in diagram documents
member.remarks:
NDiagramElement enhances its base NDiagramNode with the following features:
Ability to reside in diagram document
NDiagramElement implements the INDiagramElement interface, which is a required interface for all document elements, containers and composites.
Attributes
Since NDiagramElement implements the INDiagramElement interface, which on its turn derives from INElement, it adds support for attribites (implements the INAttributeContainer interface).
Context menu editing
NDiagramElement implements the INContextMenuEditable interface. In this way all NDiagramElement derivates can be edited via context menus. NDiagramElement adds support for the Properties verb.
History support
All property and method calls of NDiagramElement and its derivates are protected by history. That is why NDiagramElement tries to cashe a reference to an instance of the NElementHistoryService (if the current context can provide a reference to this service). It also provides a set of protected methods, which safely delegate to the NElementHistoryService. You can use them to make your derived classes history aware.
Measurements
NDiagramElement implements INMeasurements interface and thus subscribes for logical measurement unit conversions. Derived classes can override the ConvertMeasurementUnit method to convert all logical measurements they contain.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NDiagramNode
member.summary: The NDiagramNode abstract class serves as base class for all nodes, which reside in diagram scenes (i.e. documents and views)
member.remarks:
Derived classes can benefit from the following NDiagramNode functionality:
INNode interface implementation
NDiagramNode implements the INNode interface, which is a required interface for all INNode scene containers and composites.
Z Order
NDiagramNode impements the INZOrderable interface, so you can change the ZOrder of any NDiagramNode derivate.
Events
NDiagramNode tries to connect to an instance of the NDiagramEventSinkService. The event sink service to which the node is connected can be obtained from the EventSinkService property. It also provides derived classes with core implementation for firing NodePropertyChanging and NodePropertyChanged events.
Smart paint
NDiagramNode tries to connect to an instance of the NDiagramSmartPaintService. The smart paint service to which the node is connected can be obtained from the SmartPaintService property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NLayer
member.summary: The NLayer class serves as primary drawing document content container
member.remarks:
NLayer enhances its base NStyleableElement with the following features:
Free composition
NLayer implements the INDiagramElementComposite interface, so you can freely insert and remove elements from a layer.
Painting
By implementing the INPaintable interface layers propagate the painting to their children. Layers can also split the painting into Shadow and Appearance passes, so that the shadows of all nodes inside one layer are painted before their content.
Hit tests Implemented is the INHitTest interface to indicate that the NLayer descendants can be hittested.
Layers can be automatically shown/hidden based on the current zoom factor. If the EnableShowInZoomRange property is set to true, the layer will only be shown if the current zoom factor is in the range specified by the MinShowZoomFactor and MaxShowZoomFactor properties.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayer.EnableShowInZoomRange
member.summary: Gets/sets whether the layer should only be shown if the current zoom factor is in the Min/Max Zoom factor range specified by the MinShowZoomFactor and MaxShowZoomFactor properties.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayer.MinShowZoomFactor
member.summary: Gets/sets the minimal zoom factor after which the layer is shown. If the EnableShowInZoomRange is set to true the layer is only shown, if the current zoom factor is larger than this setting. By default set to 0.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.NLayer.MaxShowZoomFactor
member.summary: Gets/sets the maximum zoom factor below which the layer is shown. If the EnableShowInZoomRange is set to true the layer is only shown, if the current zoom factor is smaller than this setting. By default set to Single.MaxValue.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NPointElement
member.summary: The NPointElement class represents a point, which is displayed directly to the device.
member.remarks: NPointElement is used to display a shape from the NPointShapeStencil. Since this shape is displayed directly to the device only the point location is measured in scene coordinates. The point size is always measured in device coordinates (e.g. pixels) and is not dependent on view scale or the drawing scale.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NTransformableElement
member.summary: The NTransformableElement abstract class respresents a styleable element, which contains a local transformation
member.remarks:
NTransformableElement implements the INTransformable interface and serves as base class for all DOM elements, which require to be transformed.
For speed optimizations all transformable derivates maintain cashed scene information (scene cashe). Since the scene cashe can change, if the transformation of an ancestor has changed, the NTransformableElement also implements the INAncestorTransformObserver interface and invalidates the scene cashe, when an ancestor transform changes or the local element transform has changed.
Derived classes can also invalidate the scene cashe, whenever they feel that it is not up to date.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NTransformableElement.OnTransformChanging(Nevron.GraphicsCore.NMatrix2DF)
member.summary: Called when the transformation of the element is about to change
member.remarks: If this is a container element, the implementation will first check whether the change is accepted by all ancestor transform observers. It will then fire a NodeTransformChanging event if the element is connected to an event sink service.
member.returns: true if change is acceptable, otherwise false

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NTransformableElement.OnTransformChanged
member.summary: Called when the transformation of the element has changed
member.remarks: This implementation will first invalidate the scene cashe. If this is a container element, the implementation will then notify all ancestor transform observers about the change. Finally the implementation will fire a NodeTransformChanged event if the element is connected to an event sink service.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NTextPrimitive
member.summary: The NTextPrimitive class represents a primitive model, which is used to display wrapped or stretched text
member.remarks:
The NTextPrimitive extends the base NPrimitiveModel with the following features:
Text Texts implement the INText interface, which is mandatory for all nodes which can display text
Painting Texts can be painted. That is why they implement the INPaintable interface
Hit tests Texts can be the result of hit tests, hence they implement the INHitTestable interface.
Inplace editing Texts can be inplace edited, hence they implement the INInplaceEditable interface.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NPathPrimitive
member.summary: The NPathPrimitive class represents a primitive model, whose content is a GraphicsPath
member.remarks:
The NPathPrimitive extends the base NModel with the following features:
Points NPathPrimitive implements the INPoints interface, thus exposing a set of base and control points (in scene coordinates), which can be used to modify the path model.
Painting Paths can be painted. That is why they implement the INPaintable interface
Hit tests Paths can be the result of hit tests, hence they implement the INHitTestable interface.

member.remarks: This method is called by views when this model is the focused model. The implementation will fire the NodeKeyUp event for this model. If it was not handled it will bubble the event to the previous INKeyboardEventHandler implementor in the scene hierachy.
member.param: event arguments received from a view

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NDecorator.IsInputKey(System.Windows.Forms.Keys)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified key is an input key
member.remarks: This method is called by views when this model is the focused model. The implementation will first invoke the QueryIsInputKey method of the document for this model. If the key is not an input key for this model it will call the QueryIsInputKey method again passing as argument the document itself.
member.returns: true if the key is an input key, otherwise false

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NDecorator.IsInputChar(System.Char)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified character is an input charecter
member.remarks: This method is called by views when this model is the focused model. The implementation will first invoke the QueryIsInputChar method of the document for this model. If the key is not an input key for this model it will call the QueryIsInputChar method again passing as argument the document itself.
member.returns: true if the character is an input character, otherwise false

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NGroup
member.summary: The NGroup class represents a composite shape, which can also aggregate one or more shapes
member.remarks: The aggregated shapes can be obtained from the Shapes property. It is possible to select and delete all the shapes contained in a group. When the group has no shapes it is considered empty. You can prevent the group from becoming empty, by setting the CanBeEmpty property to false. You can instruct the group to automatically destroy itself, if it becomes empty by setting the AutoDestroy property to true.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NShape
member.summary: The NShape class is an aggregate model, which represents an object from the real world, concept or abstraction
member.remarks:
Shapes are the primary diagram building blocks. Shapes can be connected with each other and form complex relationships. There are two types of shapes:
1D Shapes
These are shapes, which are treated as lines and are usually used to connect 2D shapes. 1D shapes have start and end plugs, which can be connected to the ports of other shapes. The start and end plugs are anchored to the shape start and end points. In the context of graphs, 1D Shapes are treated as graph edges (if the GraphPart property is set to true). In the context of routing, 1D Shapes are not treated as obstacles. Only the bridgeable paths of bridgeable 1D shapes can display bridges.
2D Shapes
These are shape which are treated as boxes. 2D shapes do not have plugs. In the context of graphs, 2D Shapes are treated as graph vertices (if the GraphPart property is set to true). In the context of routing, 2D Shapes are treated as obstacles (the RouteObstacleType property is taken into account). Bridgeable paths inside 2D shapes do not display bridges.
Whether the shape is 1D or 2D is controlled by the ShapeType property. The shape type influences the default shape behavior.
Each type of shape can have the following optional elements:
Labels
Labels are texts, which can be anchored to different aspects of the shape or to the models it aggregates. The shape labels are accessible from the Labels property.
Control points
Control points are used for the interactive modification of the shape geometry. The shape control points are accessible from the ControlPoints property.
Ports
Ports are connection points to which multiple plugs can be connected. The shape ports are accessible from the Ports property.
Decorators
Decorators are elements which decorate the shape with different effects (like borders, expand collapse etc). The decorators are accessible from the Decorators property.
By design a shape will only create the elements it needs (e.g. some shapes may not have Labels, Control Points, Ports and/or Decorators). You can programmatically create and destroy the optional shape elements with the help of the CreateShapeElements and DestroyShapeElements methods.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NStep3Connector
member.summary: The NStep3Connector class represents a step connector, which connects its start and end points in three steps
member.remarks:
The position of the middle segment can be controlled in two modes:
Percent the middle segment is aligned to the percent location relative to the start and end points. For example 50% is the middle between the start and end points. The percent is controlled by the MiddleControlPointPercent property.
Offset the middle segment is aligned to aligned to the far or near side of the start and end points with the specified offset. For example offset 10 positions the middle segment at 10 on the far side of the start and end points. Offset -10 positions the middle segment at -10 on the near side of the start and end points. The offset is controlled by the MiddleControlPointOffset property.
The mode is determined by the value of the UseMiddleControlPointPercent property.

member.summary: The NRoutableConnector class represents a mutable polypath shape, which can automatically avoid obstacles in its path
member.remarks:
The NRoutableConnector extends its base NMutablePolyPathShape with the following features:
ConnectorType property This property is used to control the type of primitive used by the connector. The routing and reflexive abilities of the connector depend on the value of this property.
Routing ability The routable connector implements the INRoutableShape interface and thus declares its ability to be routed (e.g. reshaped to avoids obstacles).
Reflex ability The routable connector edge implements the INReflexiveShape interface and thus declares its ability to be reflexed (e.g. reshaped to bend around the reflexed shape).

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NConnectionPoint
member.summary: The NConnectionPoint abstract class represents a point, which can be a member of a connection. It serves as base class for ports and plugs.
member.remarks:
Each connection point has the potential to be connected to only one Inward Port. The Inward Port to which the connection point is currently connected is obtained from the InwardPort property.
When a connection point is connected it creates a dependency, between its shape and the inward port shape. When the inward port shape is changed the dependent shapes are automatically updates. The type of dependency update depends on the type of connected point. For example: start and end plugs will update the shape start and end points, outward ports will translate (rotate) the shape to match the inward port location and direction.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.NPort
member.summary: The NPort class represents a connection point, which can be anchored to a specific parameter of the shape to which they belong or to an aggregated model, which the shape contains.
member.remarks:
The Type property of the port defines much of the port behavior. It can take the following values:
Inward (the default)
Inward ports cannot be connected. However multiple plugs and outward ports of other shapes can be connected to an inward port.
Outward
Outward ports can be connected to inward ports. Plugs cannot be connected to outward ports. Only one outward port of a shape can be connected at time. This means that whenever an outward port is connected, both plugs and the currently connected outward port (if any) are automatically disconnected.
Inward and Outward
Behaves as an inward and outward port.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.NStencil.GetServiceOfType(System.Type)
member.summary: Gets a reference to a service of the specified type
member.remarks: This implementation will return null for service of type NDiagramSmartPaintService. For all other types of services it will call the document implementation of the INServiceProvider interface. In this way models hosted in stencils cannot be invalidated.
member.returns: service instance or null if a service of this type cannot be located

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate
member.summary: Defines the possible ways in which a model can be resized when the aggregate in which it resides is resized

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.UseAggregateSettings
member.summary: Uses the settings of the aggregate to which the model resides. In this mode the model will use the NAggregateModel ResizeAggregatedModels setting.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.DoNothing
member.summary: The aggregate does not change the position and size of the model

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.Scale1D
member.summary: The aggregate scales the start and end points of the model

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.RepositionOnly
member.summary: The aggregate only repositions the model so that its pin preserves it relative location to the aggregate model bounds

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.RepositionYOnly
member.summary: The aggregate only repositions the model so that its pin Y coordinate preserves it relative location to the aggregate model bounds

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.RepositionXOnly
member.summary: The aggregate only repositions the model so that its pin X coordinate preserves it relative location to the aggregate model bounds

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.AffineScaleY
member.summary: The aggregate applies affine Y scaling to the model. If the model is rotated this can break its orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.AffineScaleYRepositionX
member.summary: The aggregate applies affine Y scaling to the model and preserves the model pin X coordinate relative to the aggregate model bounds. If the model is rotated this can break its orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.AffineScaleX
member.summary: The aggregate applies affine X scaling to the model. If the model is rotated this can break its orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.AffineScaleXRepositionY
member.summary: The aggregate applies affine X scaling to the model and preserves the model pin Y coordinate relative to the aggregate model bounds. If the model is rotated this can break its orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.AffineScale
member.summary: The aggregate applies affine X and Y scaling to the model. If the model is rotated this can break its orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.CartesianScaleY
member.summary: The aggregate applies cartesian Y scaling to the model. This setting will preserve the model orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.CartesianScaleYRepositionY
member.summary: The aggregate applies cartesian Y scaling to the model and preserves the model pin Y coordinate relative to the aggregate model bounds. This setting will preserve the model orthogonality.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.ResizeInAggregate.CartesianScaleYRepositionX
member.summary: The aggregate applies cartesian Y scaling to the model and preserves the model pin X coordinate relative to the aggregate model bounds. This setting will preserve the model orthogonality.

member.summary: The aggregate applies cartesian Y scaling to the model and preserves the model pin position relative to the aggregate model bounds. This setting will preserve the model orthogonality.

member.summary: The aggregate applies cartesian X scaling to the model. This setting will preserve the model orthogonality.

member.summary: Enumerates the possible shape translation slaves

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.ReflexiveShapes
member.summary: Translate with shapes which reflex it (e.g. 1D shapes whose both plugs are connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.IncomingShapes
member.summary: Translate with the incoming shapes (e.g. 1D shapes whose end plug is connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.OutgoingShapes
member.summary: Translate with the outgoing shapes (e.g. 1D shapes whose start plug is connected to the shape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.FromShape
member.summary: Translate with the FROM shape (e.g. the shape to which the start plug is connected). Applicable for 1D shapes

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.ToShape
member.summary: Translate with the TO shape (e.g. the shape to which the end plug is connected)). Applicable for 1D shapes

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.ConnectedShapes
member.summary: Translate with all possible connected shapes (e.g. IncomingShapes + OutgoingShapes + FromShape + ToShape)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.DestinationShapes
member.summary: Translate with destination shapes (e.g. the shapes which are connected to the end plug of outgoing shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.SourceShapes
member.summary: Translate with source shapes (e.g. the shapes which are connected to the start plug of incoming shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.NeighbourShapes
member.summary: Translate with neighbour shapes (e.g. DestinationShapes + SourceShapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.SuccessorShapes
member.summary: Translate with successor shapes (e.g. DestinationShapes + the successor shapes of the destination shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.PredecessorShapes
member.summary: Translate with predecessor shapes (e.g. SourceShapes + the predecessor shapes of the source shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.AccessibleShapes
member.summary: Translate with all accessible shapes (e.g. NeighbourShapes + the accessible shapes of the neighbour shapes)

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.TranslationSlavesMask.All
member.summary: All

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode

member.summary: Automatically determines an angle, which is formed by the line connecting the port location with the anchor model center.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.AutoCenterInverted
member.summary: Automatically determines an angle, which is formed by the line connecting the port location with the anchor model center.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.AutoPrev
member.summary: Same as auto center, but angle is inverted to 180 degrees

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.AutoPrevInverted
member.summary: Same as auto prev, but angle is inverted to 180 degrees

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.AutoNext
member.summary: Automatically determines an angle, which is formed by the line connecting the port anchor point and the next point

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.AutoNextInverted
member.summary: Same as auto next, but angle is inverted to 180 degrees

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.Custom
member.summary: Use the CustomDirectionAngle angle property, which defines the angle.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.PointPortDirectionMode.None
member.summary: No angle is provided and the connected shapes do not rotate

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.BoundsPortDirectionMode
member.summary: Enumerates the modes in which a bounds port can determine its direction angle

member.summary: Automatically determines an angle, which is formed by the line connecting the port location with the model center.

member.summary: Same as AutoCenter but angle is inverted to 180 degrees.

member.summary: Automatically determines the bounds side, and returns a normal vector angle to this side (e.g. 0, 90, 180, 270 degrees).

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.BoundsPortDirectionMode.AutoSideInverted
member.summary: Same as AutoSide but angle is inverted to 180 degrees.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.BoundsPortDirectionMode.Custom
member.summary: Use the CustomDirectionAngle angle property, which defines the angle.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.BoundsPortDirectionMode.None
member.summary: No angle is provided and the connected shapes do not rotate

member.summary: The NImageExporter class is used to export an entire drawing document, or only portions of it to image.

member.summary: Constructs an image export object associated with the specified document
member.param: document assosiated with the image exporter (cannot be null)

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.LocalizationContextName
member.summary: Gets the localization context name for this class.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.GrayScale
member.summary: Specifies whether the generated image must be rendered in gray scales
member.remarks: By default set to false.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.PixelFormat
member.summary: Controls the pixel format of the image
member.remarks: The pixel format determines the format in which the image is generated. By default set to Format24bppRgb. If you want to generate an image with an alpha channel you need to set this property to Format32bppArgb.
member.example:
Configure the image exporter to generate a transparent image (if of course some of the fill effects have been set as transparent).
imageExporter.PixelFormat = PixelFormat.Format32bppArgb;

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.ExportBounds
member.summary: Gets/sets the bounds of the exported content (in scene coordinates)
member.remarks: By default set to the document bounds

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.ExportBoundsPadding
member.summary: Specifies the default padding, which you can apply to the export bounds from the visual interface of the exporter
member.remarks: By default set to the document.Settings.ExportBoundsPadding

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.KnownBoundsTable
member.summary: Represents a named bounds table used by the visual export editor
member.remarks: By default the table has only one dictionary entry - ("Document" = Document Bounds)

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.RenderToBitmap
member.summary: Renders the defined image content into a bitmap.
member.returns: bitmap with rendered image content

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.CopyToClipboard
member.summary: Copies the defined image content as a bitmap into the clipboard
member.example:
The following example places a bitmap in the clipboard.
imageExporter.CopyToClipboard();

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NImageExporter.CopyToClipboardAsEMF
member.summary: Copies the defined image content as an EMF (Extended Metafile) into the clipboard

The following code places an EMF (Extended Metafile) in the clipboard.
imageExporter.CopyToClipboardAsEMF();

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Extensions.NPersistencyManager
member.summary: The NPersistencyManager class facilitates the persistency management of different document types.
member.remarks:
The persistency manager serializes/deserializes a persistent document, which is divided in sections. Each section represents a named object, serialized in the persistent document. This class can be instanced when needed:
NPersistencyManager persistencyManager = new NPersistencyManager();

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGrouping
member.summary: Base class for all data grouping algorithms.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGrouping.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGrouping.RoundedRanges
member.summary: Determines whether to round the ranges calculated in the Classify method or not. By default set top false. Note that the rounding of the data ranges will produce "nicer" numbers for the map legend but may alter the way the algorithm clssifies the data points. So it is recommended not to use rounding for a small number of data points.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGrouping.Classify(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingEqualDistribution
member.summary: Also known as quantiles, this method allows for unequally sized data intervals and involves adjustment of the interval limits until an equal number of data points can be slotted into each interval.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingEqualDistribution.Classify(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingEqualInterval
member.summary: Also known as equal ranges (or steps), this method involves division of the entire data range into equally sized intervals.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingEqualInterval.Classify(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingOptimal
member.summary: Uses the Jenks-Caspall optimal data grouping algorithm.
member.remarks: The algorithm is based on iterative re-cycling: the values on the edge of each class, with the mean of their own class and the average of the next class. If a value closer to the mean of the neighboring class, it will be moved into this. The process is repeated iteratively until no further optimization is possible.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NDataGroupingOptimal.Classify(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Double},System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the specified number of data ranges (classes) for the given set of data points (distinct values).
member.param: The data points to classify sorted in ascending order.
member.returns: An array of doubles representing the data ranges. For example an array {0, 12, 32.1} means that there are 3 data ranges: [0, 12), [12, 32.1) and [32.1, Infinity).

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.PolygonLabelingMode.BoundsCenter
member.summary: Labels are placed at the center of the polygon's bounding box if it is inside the polygon. If it is not, the Optimal rendering mode is used.

member.summary: Labels are placed at the centroid of the polygon if it is inside the polygon. If it is not, the Optimal rendering mode is used.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.PolygonLabelingMode.Optimal
member.summary: Labels are placed at an optimal position in the polygon. This produces the best results, but is the most computationally expensive mode.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.LabelVisibility.NoOverlapByValue
member.summary: Labels that overlap other labels will be hidden based on the value associated to the shape by the fill rule.

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.LabelVisibility.All

member.summary: The Eckert IV projection, used for world maps, is a pseudocylindrical and equal-area.
member.remarks: The central meridian is straight, the 180th meridians are semi-circles, other meridians are elliptical. Scale is true along the parallel at 40:30 North and South.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NEckertVIProjection
member.summary: The Eckert VI projection, used for maps of the world, is pseudocylindrical and equal area.
member.remarks: The central meridian and all parallels are at right angles, all other meridians are sinusoidal curves. Shape distortion increases at the poles. Scale is correct at standard parallels of 49:16 North and South.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NHammerProjection
member.summary: The Hammer projection is an equal-area map projection, described by Ernst Hammer in 1892.
member.remarks: Directly inspired by the Aitoff projection, Hammer suggested the use of the equatorial form of the Lambert azimuthal equal-area projection instead of Aitoff's use of the azimuthal equidistant projection. Visually, the Aitoff and Hammer projections are very similar but the Hammer has seen more use because of its equal-area property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NKavrayskiyVIIProjection
member.summary: The Kavrayskiy VII is a map projection invented by V. V. Kavrayskiy in 1939 for use as a general purpose pseudocylindrical projection.
member.remarks: Like the Robinson projection, it is a compromise intended to produce good quality maps with low distortion overall. It scores well in that respect compared to other popular projections, such as the Winkel Tripel, despite straight, evenly-spaced parallels and a simple formulation. It has been used in the former Soviet Union but is almost unknown in the Western world.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NMercatorProjection
member.summary: Implements the Mercator projection.
member.remarks: This map projection introduced in 1569 by Gerardus Mercator. It is often described as a cylindrical projection, but it must be derived mathematically. The meridians are equally spaced, parallel vertical lines, and the parallels of latitude are parallel, horizontal straight lines, spaced farther and farther apart as their distance from the Equator increases. This projection is widely used for navigation charts, because any straight line on a Mercator-projection map is a line of constant true bearing that enables a navigator to plot a straight-line course. It is less practical for world maps because the scale is distorted; areas farther away from the equator appear disproportionately large. On a Mercator projection, for example, the landmass of Greenland appears to be greater than that of the continent of South America; in actual area, Greenland is smaller than the Arabian Peninsula.

member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NMercatorProjection.ToString
member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NMillerCylindricalProjection
member.summary: The Miller cylindrical projection is a modified Mercator projection, proposed by Osborn Maitland Miller (1897-1979) in 1942.
member.remarks: The parallels of latitude are scaled by a factor of 0.8, projected according to Mercator, and then the result is divided by 0.8 to retain scale along the equator.

member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NMollweideProjection
member.summary: The Mollweide projection is a pseudocylindrical map projection generally used for global maps of the world (or sky). Also known as the Babinet projection, homolographic projection, or elliptical projection.
member.remarks: As its more explicit name Mollweide equal area projection indicates, it sacrifices fidelity to angle and shape in favor of accurate depiction of area. It is used primarily where accurate representation of area takes precedence over shape, for instance small maps depicting global distributions.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NOrthographicProjection
member.summary: Orthographic projection is a perspective (or azimuthal) projection, in which the sphere is projected onto a tangent plane. It depicts a hemisphere of the globe as it appears from outer space. The shapes and areas are distorted, particularly near the edges, but distances are preserved along parallels.
member.remarks: You can control the central meridian of the projection using the property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NRobinsonProjection
member.summary: The Robinson projection is a map projection made in 1988 to show the entire world at once. It was specifically created in an attempt to find the good compromise to the problem of readily showing the whole globe as a flat image.
member.remarks: The projection is neither equal-area nor conformal, abandoning both for a compromise. The creator felt this produced a better overall view than could be achieved by adhering to either. The meridians curve gently, avoiding extremes, but thereby stretch the poles into long lines instead of leaving them as points. Hence distortion close to the poles is severe but quickly declines to moderate levels moving away from them. The straight parallels imply severe angular distortion at the high latitudes toward the outer edges of the map, a fault inherent in any pseudocylindrical projection.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NRobinsonProjection.ProjectPoint(Nevron.GraphicsCore.NPointF)
member.summary: Projects the specified point.
member.returns: The transformed point.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NRobinsonProjection.DeprojectPoint(Nevron.GraphicsCore.NPointF)
member.summary: Deprojects the specified point to recover its longitude and lattitude.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NRobinsonProjection.ToString
member.summary: Returns a System.String that represents the current System.Object.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NStereographicProjection
member.summary: The stereographic projection is a particular mapping (function) that projects a sphere onto a plane.
member.remarks: The fact that no map from the sphere to the plane can accurately represent both angles (and thus shapes) and areas is the fundamental problem of cartography. In general, area-preserving map projections are preferred for statistical applications, because they behave well with respect to integration, while angle-preserving (conformal) map projections are preferred for navigation. The stereographic projection falls into the second category.

member.summary: Default constructor.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NVanDerGrintenProjection
member.summary: The van der Grinten projection is neither equal-area nor conformal. It projects the entire Earth into a circle, though the polar regions are subject to extreme distortion.

remarks.para: The projection was the first of four proposed by Alphons J. van der Grinten in 1904, and, unlike most projections, is an arbitrary geometric construction on the plane. It was made famous when the National Geographic Society adopted it as their reference map of the world from 1922 until 1988.

member.summary: Wagner VI is a pseudocylindrical whole Earth map projection. Like the Robinson projection, it is a compromise projection, not having any special attributes other than a pleasing, low distortion appearance.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Maps.NWinkelTripelProjection
member.summary: The Winkel Tripel projection (Winkel III) is a modified azimuthal map projection proposed by Oswald Winkel in 1921. The projection is the arithmetic mean of the equirectangular projection and the Aitoff projection.
member.remarks: Goldberg and Gott show that the Winkel Tripel is arguably the best overall whole-earth map projection known, producing very small distance errors, small combinations of ellipticity and area errors, and the smallest skewness of any map. In 1998, the Winkel Tripel projection replaced the Robinson projection as the standard projection for world maps made by the National Geographic Society.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NConstrainedCellsLayout
member.summary: The NConstrainedCellsLayout class represents a directed cells layout, the cells placement of which can be constrained in the layout direction
member.remarks:
Constrained cells layouts typically switch to a new lane when a constrain is broken. There are two ways for constraining the layout, which is controlled by the ConstrainMode property:
Size
the layout will switch to a new lane, if the next placable cell will go outside the respective side of the container client area. For a horizontal layout this is the right container side. For a vertical layout this is the bottom container side.
Ordinal
the layout will switch to a new lane, if the next placable cell ordinal index withing its lane, will exceed the MaxOrdinal property setting.

member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Copy constructor

member.summary: Gets/sets the mode, in which the flow layout expansion is constrained in the flow direction. By default set to Size.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NConstrainedCellsLayout.MaxOrdinal
member.summary: Gets/sets the maximum ordinal to which the layout can expand. Only applicable if ConstrainMode is set to Ordinal.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NFlowLayout
member.summary: The NFlowLayout class represents a constrained cells layout, which arranges the cells in horizontal or vertical lanes.
member.remarks: The flow layout is a typical constrained cells layout, which does not preserve tabular metrics. That is why you can specify whether the layout must justify the the cells in each lane. This is done by the JustifyLanes properties.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode
member.summary: Enumerates the modes for stack layouts

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode.None
member.summary: The stack layout does not attemp to resolve the available/insufficient area problem

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode.Equal
member.summary: The stack inflates the size of each object with equal amount of space in order to resolve the available/insufficient area problem

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode.Proportional
member.summary: The stack inflates the size each object with amount of space proportional to its size in order to resolve the available/insufficient area problem

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode.First
member.summary: The stack inflates the size of the first object in the stack, then the size of the second one and so on until the available/insufficient area problem is ressolved

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.StackMode.Last
member.summary: The stack inflates the size of the last object in the stack, then the size of the object before it and so on until the available/insufficient area problem is ressolved

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode
member.summary: Enumerates the modes for dock layoutss

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.None
member.summary: The dock layout does not attemp to resolve the available/insufficient area problem

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.Equal
member.summary: The dock inflates the size of each object with equal amount of space in order to resolve the available/insufficient area problem

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.CenterFirst
member.summary: The dock inflates the size of the center object in the dock, then the size of the pair formed by the previous and the next one and so on until the available/insufficient area problem is ressolved

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.SidesFirst
member.summary: The dock inflates the size of the pair formed by the first and the last object in the dock, then the size of the pair formed by the next and the previous one and so on until the available/insufficient area problem is ressolved

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.ForwardOrder
member.summary: The bodies are resized in the order they were added

member.name: F:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.DockMode.ReverseOrder
member.summary: The bodies are resized in reverse order to the order they were added

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NForceEnvironment
member.summary: The NForceEnvironment class is used to encapsulate the force directed layout settings related to the global environment in which the forces operate
member.remarks:
The force enviroment controls the amount of force actually applied to the vertices in a force directed layout. It defines the notion of global and local temperatures.
If the UseGlobalTemperature property is set to true, the enviroment will gradually decrease the area in which the vertices are allowed to move (e.g. will perform global cooling). At the first iteration this area will be equal to the MaxForce property, and will gradually decrease to 0, as the layout progresses.
If the UseLocalTemperature property is set to ture, the enviroment will assign a local temperature to each vertex. The force applied to the vertex is magnified by its local temperature.
If the vertex is constantly moving in approximately the same direction (plus-minus the allowed deviation controlled by the LocalDirectionDeviation property), its temperature will increase (with the value specified by the LocalWarmingStep property) and it will speed up.
If the vertex is oscilating or rotating its temperature will decrease and it will slow down (with the value specified by the LocalCoolingStep property).
The maximum value of the local temperature is specified by the MaxLocalTemperature property.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NForceEnvironment.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce
member.summary: The NBarycenterForce class represents an edge force, which tries to place connected vertices at their barycenter (center of gravity)
member.remarks:
The barycenter force is attractive by definition. It tries to collapse the vertices to the center of their mass. The force magnitude experienced by the vertices is specified by the following formulas:
vertex1Force = AttractionCoefficient * vertex1.Mass / (vertex1.Mass + vertex2.Mass)
vertex2Force = AttractionCoefficient * vertex2.Mass / (vertex1.Mass + vertex2.Mass)
The Mass parameter can be specified on a per vertex basis. If a vertex does not provide a concrete value for this parameter it is by default considered to be 1.

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce.#ctor(Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce)
member.summary: Copy constructor

member.summary: Called before the force is used in the specified graph

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterForce.AttractionCoefficient
member.summary: Gets/sets the attraction coefficient, which affects the power with which connected vertices attract each other. Should be a value in the the [0;1] range

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NDesiredDistanceForce
member.summary: The NDesiredDistanceForce is a force, which couples an attraction force (edge force), and a repulsion force (vertex force). The two forces balance each other when the distance between connected vertices is equal to the specified desired distance.
member.remarks:
The attraction force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
AttractionCoefficient * Math.Pow(distance, 2) / Math.Pow(DesiredDistance, 2)
The repulsion force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
RepulsionCoefficient * Math.Pow(DesiredDistance, 2) / Math.Pow(distance, 2)
Provided that the RepulsionCoefficient and AttractionCoefficient are equal, the two forces balance each other at DesiredDistance.

member.summary: Gets/sets the repulsion coefficient, which affects the power with which vertices repel each other.

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NDesiredDistanceForce.AttractionCoefficient
member.summary: Gets/sets the attraction coefficient, which affects the power with which connected vertices attract each other.

member.summary: Gets/sets the desired distance between between a pair of connected vertices

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NElectricalForce
member.summary: The NElectricalForce class represents a vertices force, which simulates the electrical repulsion between two ellectrically charged particles.
member.remarks:
The ellectrical force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
(RepulsionCoefficient * Math.Pow(NominalDistance, 2) * Novertex1.ElectricalCharge * vertex2.ElectricalCharge) / (distance * distance)
Provided that the electrical charges are equal in sign (which is the most common case), the ellectrical force is repulsive and decreases in an inverse square law as the distance between the vertices is increased.
The ElectricalCharge parameter can be specified on a per vertex basis. If a vertex does not provide a concrete value for this parameter it is by default considered to be 1.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NForce
member.summary: The NForce class serves as base class for all types of forces, which can be used in force directed layouts
member.remarks:
Each force can be enabled or disabled, which is controlled by the Enabled property. When disabled the force will not be taken into account by the force directed layout. This lets you easily turn on/off different force configurations.
Provided that the force is enabled, it activates at the pass, specified by the ActivationPass property. The force directed layout will perform as many passes as the maximum ActivationPass setting of all currently enabled forces.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce
member.summary: The NGravityForce class represents a global force, which simulates a gravity attraction to the current barycenter of the graph
member.remarks:
The gravity force simulates an attraction to the current barycenter of the graph, which is experienced by all vertices in the graph. The force magnitude is computed by the following formula:
AttractionCoefficient * (1 + vertex.Degree * DegreeFactor) * (Barycenter - vertex.Center)

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.name: M:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce.#ctor(Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce)
member.summary: Copy constructor

member.summary: Gets/sets the attraction coefficient, which affects the power with which vertices are attracted to the barycenter

member.name: P:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NGravityForce.DegreeFactor
member.summary: Gets/sets the degree factor, which affects the tendency vertices with higher degree to be more attracted to the barycenter

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NMagneticFieldForce
member.summary: The NMagneticFieldForce is an edge force, which is used to impose an edge orientation constrain
member.remarks:
The magnetic force magnitute is computed by the following formula:
TorsionCoefficient * Math.Pow(distance, DistancePower) * Math.Pow(angle, AnglePower)
where angle is the angle, which the edge forms with the magnetic field.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NSpringForce
member.summary: The NSpringForce class represents an edge force, which simulates a spring connecting adjacent vertices.
member.remarks:
The spring force magnitude formula can take two forms based on the SpringForceLaw property value:
Logarithmic
edge.SpringStiffness * Math.Log(LogBase, distance / edge.SpringLength)
HookeLaw
edge.SpringStiffness * (d - edge.SpringLength)
In both forms the spring force becomes repulsive, if the distance is smaller than the spring length, and becomes attractive, when the distance is larger than the spring length. That is, the spring force aims to make the distance between connected vertices equal to the natural (zero energy) of the spring.
The SpringStiffness and SpringLength parameters can be specified on a per edge basis. If an edge does not provide a concrete value for either of these parameters, the default values are obtained from the SpringStiffness and SpringLength properties respectively.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NBarycenterLayout
member.summary: The NBarycenterLayout class represents a force directed layout, which implements the barycenter layout method.
member.remarks:
The barycenter layout method splits the input graph into a set of fixed and free vertices. Fixed vertices are nailed to the corners of a strictly convex polygon, while free vertices are placed in the barycenter of their neighbours.
In case there are no fixed vertices this will place all vertices at a single point, which is obviously not a good graph drawing. That is why the barycenter layout needs at least three fixed vertices.
The minimal amount of fixed vertices is specified by the MinFixedVerticesCount property. If the input graph does not have that many fixed vertices, the layout will automatically forefill this requirement. This is done by fixing the vertices with the smallest degree.
The attractive force pulling the vertices towards their barycenter is represented by an instance of the NBarycenterForce class, accessible from the BarycenterForce property.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NForceDirectedLayout
member.summary: The NForceDirectedLayout class is a graph layout, which layouts the graph vertices and edges, according to the forces acting on them. It serves as base class for all types of force directed layouts.
member.remarks:
The force directed layout basically implements an iterative algorithm, which tries to minimize the physical energy (reach equilibrium), enduced by the forces in the provided graph. Different force directed layouts use different sets of forces, however all forces are derived from the base NForce class.
In general the algorithm performs the following steps:
Fixed vertex placement
fixed vertices are such vertices, which cannot be moved in both X and Y directions. Their initial placement is controlled by an instance of the NFixedVertexPlacement class, accessible from the FixedVertexPlacement property.
Free vertex placement
free vertices are such vertices, which can be moved in X or Y directions. Their initial placement is controlled by an instance of the NFreeVertexPlacement class, accessible from the FreeVertexPlacement property.
Iteration phase
the iteration phase is repeated until all enabled forces are activated. At each iteration phase the algorithm tries to reach equilibrium in the number of iterations specified by the MaxIterations property. At each iteration the algorithm first accumulates the forces acting on all vertices and then ask the enviroment to apply them (actually move the vertices). The enviroment is represented by an instance of the NForceEnvironment class, accessible from the ForceEnvironment property.
The force directed layout provides the following optional force model:
Magnetic Field Force
The magnetic field force tries to impose an orientation of the edges in the graph. It is represented by an instance of the NMagneticFieldForce class, accessible from the MagneticFieldForce property.
Bounce Back Force
The bounce back force forces tries to additionally repel overlapping vertices. It is represented by an instance of the NBounceBackForce class, accessible from the BounceBackForce property.
Gravity Force
The gravity force forces tries to attact the vertices to the current barycenter of the graph. It is represented by an instance of the NGravityForce class, accessible from the GravityForce property.
All of the above mentioned forces are by default disabled and their activation pass is set to 1. In this way, if any of those forces is enabled, the graph will be given a chance to relax during the first pass, in which only the primary force model will act.

member.name: T:Nevron.Diagram.Layout.NSpringLayout
member.summary: The NSpringLayout class represents a force directed layout, which simulates a physical system with spring and electical forces.
member.remarks:
The spring layout represents a classical implementation of a force directed layout, with spring and electicral forces. It allows for many per vertex and per edge settings, which can seamlessly reflect the nature of the graph.
Graph vertices are threated as ellectically charged particles, which repel each other. The electical force aims to ensure that vertices should not be close together. The parameters of the electrical force are controlled by an instance of the NElectricalForce class, accessible from the ElectricalForce property.
Graph edges are threated as springs. Springs aim to ensure that the distance between adjacent vertices is approximately equal to the spring length. The parameters of the spring force are controlled by an instance of the NSpringForce class, accessible from the SpringForce property.

member.summary: Copy constructor
